MEMORANDUM OF UNDERSTANDING ON SOCIAL ASSET DIVESTITURE AND UNEMPLOYMENT POLICY March 25, 1995 Mr. Gautam Kaji Acting President World Bank 1818 H St. N.W. Washington, D.C. 20433 Dear Mr. Kaji: 1. As you know, Kazakhstan is implementing a comprehensive structural reform program aimed at moving the country toward a market economy. This program has been supported by a Rehabilitation Loan from the World Bank and an Upper Credit Tranche Standby Arrangement with the IMF. A proposed Structural Adjustment Loan has been designed for Bank-financing. 2. The Government's structural reform agenda is giving priority to: (a) developing competitive markets throughout the country; (b) reforming the enterprise and financial sectors; (c) putting in place appropriate labor/social policies; (d) resolving bottlenecks in infrastructure and energy; and (e) cleaning up the environment. Simultaneous progress on all fronts of the structural reform agenda is essential for achieving stabilization. 3. Privatization and enterprise reform is a central tenet of the Government's reform strategy. In the past, state enterprises in Kazakhstan have owned and operated social facilities. These include hospitals, polyclinics, kindergartens, summer camps, sports and recreational facilities, sanatoria, and housing and other utilities. This pattern of social service provision is no longer tenable as enterprises attempt to compete in the emerging market-based economy. Divestiture of social assets and the concomitant reduction of costs and social liability is crucial to the Government's policy of enterprise and social reform. It is also crucial to eliminate any incentives for workers to remain in enterprises simply because they want to preserve their accessibility to social services provided by them. 4. Local governments have to accommodate facilities divested from restructuring enterprises in situations where their existing social services are already under-financed. Basic social services have experienced budgetary decline of 40% in real terms since 1990, and over 80% of the health budget is now allocated to salaries and essential utilities. Many social facilities, both ex-enterprise and municipal, are operating at minimal levels due to a severe lack of critical equipment and consumables, and to a significant skilled staff shortage, their departure to other countries because of a low prestige of their work, low salaries, lack of equipment and supplies. In the short term, the sustainability of social services depends more on increasing the availability of operating resources than investment capital. Local govermments must also rationalize the structure and delivery of all essential social services, regardless of their origin. Some facilities should be merged or closed, and others should be privatized, cost recovery
 Page 2 ANNEX 1 should be increased. Technical and financial support to local governments is critical during this period of transition for essential recurrent expenditures, rehabilitation of facilities and rationalization of the overall framework for social services. 5. Enterprise restructuring and privatization is leading to higher levels of unemployment, particularly considering the past excessive staffing in state enterprises. Although only around 100,000 people were registered as unemployed at the end of 1994, estimates of actual unemployed (including hidden unemployment) were around 550,000. The Government recognizes that unemployment could reach 1 million over the next two years, and that measures to promote labor adjustment and to establish a viable social safety net are urgently needed. This would include programs to protect the unemployed as well as a strategy to ensure the delivery of social services. Rationalization of Social Services 6. The Government will carry out an inventory of enterprise social assets and design a comprehensive national strategy for their divestiture throughout the country. The strategy will aim at preserving essential priority services to as large.a population as possible, consistent with fiscal constraints. The strategy will be based on demographic characteristics, will specify appropriate service levels and standards, and will include estimated operating costs. In view of its close involvement with the program, the World Bank will be asked to review and comment on the draft National Strategy. The Government intends to implement a pilot program in two oblasts (South Kazakhstan and Pavlodar) and has requested World Bank financial support for this. The pilot program has been designed to ensure that it is replicable throughout the rest of the country. 7. Definition of essential services. The Government recognizes that some basic social services need to be transferred from enterprises to local authorities in order to facilitate the process of enterprise restructuring and to ensure the continued operation of essential social services. However, it also believes that some social services previously provided by enterprises should be restructured or privatized. The main criteria for the selection of social services, the operation of which should be continued by the local authorities, would be those with significant public benefits and social externalities, and for which privatization is not considered to be an option at least in the foreseeable future. These would include polyclinics (secondary level hospitals) and kindergartens. Excluded would be sports and recreational facilities, summer camps, sanatoria, and housing. Some essential social services with large public benefits could be operated privately and this would be encouraged where possible, but in the short term the scope for this is small and the divestiture needs of the enterprises are imminent. In due course, as the private sector develops, opportunities for private management of essential services will be pursued. 8. General service standards. The Government recognizes that the standards and norms of the divested social services should be unified with those of comparable services run by the local authorities, and that in general the standards and norms of social services previously operated by enterprises will need to be reduced to fall within expected availability of fiscal resources. For example, the ratio of children to teachers in the kindergartens will be expected to increase. Other ways of reducing average unit costs and discrepancies in service provision between different localities will also be examined. Similarly in the health sector, a review will be undertaken of appropriate levels of staffing and infrastructure (including hospital beds), and also of possible reforms in budgeting and accounting to facilitate greater efficiency and flexibility in the use of resources. The Government recognizes that there is considerable over-utilization of existing health services and that average lengths of stay in hospitals are
 ANNEX 1 Page 3 too long. Efforts will be made to reduce them. At the same time, the purpose of the national strategy is to integrate and rationalize services at the local level, not to undertake comprehensive sectoral reform. 9. Delineation of responsibilities. Basic social services are owned and operated by local governments, either raion or municipal authorities. Higher level social services, such as regional referral hospitals, are operated directly by the oblast governments. Essential social services which are divested from enterprises, on the other hand, will be operated by the raions or municipal authority. 10. Cost Recovery. The Government is revising a system of health financing. Considerations are being given to the introduction of health insurance as an additional source of financing. At the same time each group of population will have an access to a guaranteed package of free health services to be financed from health insurance revenues. Legal mechanisms for introduction of user charges for health services are being developed. The schedule of fees is to be designed; as well as standard fees throughout the country. Fee revenue will be kept largely at the point of collection in order to provide maximum incentives to the service provider. The effect of the new system of user charges will be monitored carefully. In the education sector, fees will be raised for kindergarten attendance. Considerations will be given to the design of mechanisms to ensure the continuous access to kindergartens of children of poor families. 11. Measures for local fiscal autonomy. Government policy is to mandate local administrations to continue the delivery of social services relinquished by enterprises and deemed essential. This would be done within a rationalized system of service provision. In some cases, it will be possible for enterprises and local authorities to enter into temporary arrangements so that part of the incremental cost accruing to the authorities could be met by the enterprises. However, in most cases the operation of social services previously run by enterprises will imply additional recurrent costs for local authorities, although these will be reduced by rationalization. The local budgets will benefit from increased tax revenues arising from enterprises being able to operate more productively as a result of their releasee from social sector obligations. Ways will also be explored to allow local authorities greater fiscal autonomy and increased revenue sharing to cover the costs of social services provision. In addition, consideration will be given to allowing local authorities to retain some of the revenues from the sale or rent of non-essential social infrastructure. However, until local governments have an independent and sufficient financial base, provision will be made in the central budget to be presented to Parliament for the required incremental costs of social services taken over from enterprises. Unemployment Policy 12. The Government is concerned about the social impact of the increase in open unemployment which has already begun and is forecast to accelerate in the months ahead. Labor mobility must be increased and workers should transfer from inefficient activities to new opportunities for economic growth. The Government is aware, however, that the current system of Unemployment Benefits (UB) has several weaknesses: the level of benefits is too low to provide significant relief or an effective inducement for employees to accept retrenchment; the administration of benefits is unduly complicated; the eligibility for UB overly restrictive in some ways. The structure of UB also needs to be reconsidered in ways which will protect those most in need while avoiding work disincentives for other groups. To address these concerns, the Government will implement a series of reforms. 13. First, the financial administration of the Employment Fund will be changed and its financial viability enhanced. Low priority activities (including for any wage subsidies and job creation
 Pape 4 ANNEX 1 through credit schemes) will be discontinued. The use of the Employment Fund for non-employment activities will be discontinued and the expenditure for the Fund will be made in accordance with the Republican Program of Employment and the current labor market situation. By 1996 the expenditures related to immigration will be completed from the Employment Fund. The revenue base for the Fund will be broadened; the standard rates of contribution by employers will be extended to the agricultural and budgetary sectors by 1996; and an employee-based contribution will be introduced at the same time. The levels of both employer and employee contributions will be determined from time to time after a careful and continual monitoring of the Fund, in the light of developments in the labor market, to ensure its continuing viability as an independent Fund. 14. Second, the systems for calculating UB will be restructured: (a) the basic level of UB will be determined on the basis of the minimum compensation (as approved by legislation) paid to employees in the budgetary sector; (b) the structure for the payment of UB will be as follows: (i) school leavers will not be eligible for UB but will instead receive information about their prospects and, as far as practicable, undertake further education or training or be engaged on Temporary Employment Schemes (TES); participation in either training or TES will then enable participants to build up a work history and, consequently, eligibility for UB; (ii) students leaving post-secondary education and women returning to the labor market after maternity leave will be eligible to receive the basic rate; (iii) unemployed workers in the agricultural or budgetary sectors will receive one or two times the basic rate depending on their previous earnings or on other suitable employment-related criteria. Guidelines will be prepared to define the criteria; (iv) other than the persons described in (ii) above, no benefits will be paid to people who have not worked before, although such people will still be eligible to participate in training or TES and, under separate eligibility, could still have access to family allowances. Benefits will not be payable to people who separate from a job voluntarily (guidelines will be prepared for Employment Service staff to determine eligibility); (v) retrenched workers will receive two or three times the basic rate depending on their previous earnings or on other suitable employment-related criteria. Guidelines will be prepared to define the criteria; and (vi) unemployed workers engaged in training and TES will receive a slightly higher amount than their UB entitlement. (c) unemployed people currently have eligibility for UB for only six months. If they have been unable to find work within this time, they will be allowed to reapply for a furter six months of UB provided they are willing to participate in TES when these are available. Extension of benefits will only be granted in areas of particularly high
 ANNEX 1 Page S unemployment. Guidelines will be prepared to cover the conditions under which an extension may be granted including covering the needs of people who are close to retirement and the possible application of a means-test. (d) in view of the increases proposed in the level of UB, additional payments for dependents would no longer be paid; however, recipients of UB may still apply for payments under the separate family allowances provided they meet the income test provisions applying in that scheme; (e) the pension rights of retrenched workers will be protected; and (f) the present obligation of employers for severance payments will be discontinued. 15. Third, the administration of the ES will be improved. The process of registration and application for UB will be strearnlined by changing the functions of the existing Commissions which would act in special cases only. Instead, decisions on eligibility for UB would normally be made by the ES staff themselves. A "work test" will be introduced to ensure that no one will receive UB if a suitable work opportunity arises. 16. To support the program of reform for social protection laid out in this letter, the Government of the Republic of Kazakhstan has requested a Social Protection Loan from the World Bank in an amount of US$41.1 million.  KAZAKHSTAN SOCIAL PROTECTION PROJECT ANNEX 2. EMPLOYMENT SERVICES COMPONENT A. Background 1. A project preparation team from the Australian Department of Employment, Education and Training (DEET) worked in Kazakhstan for 7 weeks in May-June 1994 to: (i) assist the Government to prepare the strategy and action plan for the strengthening of the ES; and (ii) provide some initial technical assistance to restructure the operations of the Employment Service (ES). As part of this work, the consultants reviewed Unemployment Benefit (UB) administration and current registration procedures and practices in the ES, and also examined the nature and extent of existing public works (PS) programs and retraining arrangements for the unemployed. 2. A number of policy issues were identified during the review regarding the: (i) need to simplify and standardize the system of calculating UB; (ii) level and duration of UB (including for the long-term unemployed); (iii) the requirement for notification by employers of vacancies to the ES; (iv) procedures for registration and entitlement of UB; (v) responsibility of employers for funding severance pay and retraining costs of retrenched workers; and (vi) Public Works programs and retraining of unemployed workers. 3. The preparation team worked with relevant officials in the ES to design a comprehensive five-year plan for the ES. Valuable input was received from the Regional Conference of Oblast and District Managers held at Pavlodar and the team also conducted a number of workshops with a range of ES staff to ensure that extensive consultation and a wide rage of views were incorporated into the development phase. B. Employment Services 4. The Ministry of Labor (MOL) is responsible for the operation of the ES through the Department of Employment (DOE). It has a full-time staff of approximately 2,650 and is structured on a National (Republic), Regional (Oblast) and District Office (Raion) level. In addition, there are about 1000 ancillary staff, drivers cleaners, security staff etc., many of whom are employed on a part time basis. Apart from the Republic Office based in Almaty, there are offices in each of the 21 Oblasts, and 300 Raion offices with staffing levels ranging from 4 up to 18. Functions of the Employment Service 5. The main functions of the ES as described in their regulations are: * to develop and realize state policy in the employment and social protection of the unemployed; * to analyze and forecast the labor market situation; develop and implement employment programs;
 Page 7 ANNEX 2 * to improve the job placement process, and develop specific programs for the socially vulnerable; * to interact with state management bodies, employers and trade unions on the problems of employment and social protection of the unemployed; * to develop legislative and policy statements on employment problems; * to work with international cooperation in resolving employment problems; Employment Fund 6. Until recently, the ES covered its operational, program and unemployment expenditure from the Employment Fund (EF), which was generated by a levy on employers. Falling collections and a reduction in the levy from 3% to 2% have necessitated a change to the Department's funding arrangements and these are now allocated as part of the government budgetary process. There are claims by operational and regional managers that this change has already led to a reduction in the level of funding provided to the ES and consequently a reduction in their ability to deliver services and programs effectively. 7. The fund can be used for any of the following: * payment of UB stipends and material aid, * payment during temporary invalidity, * training and retraining of the unemployed or retrenched, * paid public works, * lump sum allowances for the unemployed, * maintaining the state ES, * funding research into employment problems, * international cooperation, * payment of migration costs. 8. The Government has a policy of financial support for immigrants returning to Kazakhstan but there is no real justification for these costs to be met from the EFV. The most immediate effect of the change, which took place when the EF was included in the central budget was the loss of reserves to allow immediate responses to increased unemployment, and the loss of the additional revenue from interest. Several Oblast (or City Offices) had written to the President asking for his intervention as they had no funds to continue supporting the unemployed through benefits. While the situation persisted payment of UB was decided by the amount of money available and not the claimant's entitlement. More generally, it had also considerable impact on the cost constraints applying on the ES with less flexibility than it had under the previous arrangements when the EF was independent. As unemployment grows, the issue inevitably facing the Goverrnent will be the extent to which it is willing and able to provide direct assistance to the unemployed through welfare payments. As part of a policy reform agreed with the Government in the context of the proposed SAL, agreement has been reached with the government regarding the non use of EF funds for non employment activities, and the removal of the EF from the centra budgeL
 ANNEX 2 Page 8 9. Another area of concern is the level of collections of the EF levy. If the ES is to continue to calculate and monitor levy contributions to be made by enterprises then a more structured changes should be put in place to identify organizations that understate or avoid the levy and have penalties applied to these organizations (see Annex 2C). 10. The existing levy assessment procedures need to be reviewed to ensure that enterprises are being accurately assessed and the collection of revenue is being maximized. One option would be to remove the responsibility for collection from the individual employment offices and concentrate this work at the Oblast Office. Employment Service Delivery 11. The location of raions was determined some time ago, based on circumstances different from those likely to be encountered in the future. As conditions have changed in many districts, it is now highly desirable that a review of the locations of existing offices be undertaken and that the requirements for any additional offices over the next 3-5 years also be established. 12. Staffing is allocated to EOs on the basis of fifteen staff per one hundred thousand of population. There is minimal assessment of projected workloads nor are any specific local labor market factors taken into account when staffing levels are being set. To ensure that staffing levels reflect actual workloads and the labor market needs of particular locations, a simple staffing formula needs to be developed to provide a more flexible method of setting and reviewing staffing levels for each office. The Future 13. The first priority is to ensure that the ES is able to effectively deliver its core functions of registering jobseekers, receiving vacancies from employers, matching jobseekers with job vacancies and the assessment and payment of UB. It is essential that these functions are carried out well if the ES is to perform effectively. 14. It is considered that refinements can be made and some functions substantially developed to improve overall performance and service delivery. There are three key elements which should underpin any changes proposed for the ES. These are: * Client Focus; * Self-help for clients; and * "Multi-skilling" of ES staff 15. Client Focus means that the first priority for all staff in the office is to provide the best possible service to their customers. The client's needs should always come first, whether they be a jobseeker, an enterprise, or a person making a general inquiry. Clients visiting EOs have many different needs and have differing abilities. Self-help is based on streaming and recognizes that some clients need little additional help beyond providing them access to facilities and services which enable them to "short cut" some of the conventional ES registration or job matching procedures. Properly introduced, this approach enables significant savings in the numbers of staff required to handle growing unemployment queues.
 Page 9 ANNEX 2 16. Multi skilling means equipping staff with additional skills which would enable them to carry out the duties of a number of different functions in the employment office. The objective of multi- skilling is to provide staff the capacity to respond to increasing workloads more quickly and at the same time to ensure that the qualify of service to the client is not diminished by staff changes. It also provides staff with a greater understanding of the overall activities of the office and encourages greater teamwork. The multi-skilling of staff would be an important feature in streamlining the ES. In addition, a major component of any changes being implemented would be the work done on staff training and development. Unemployment Benefit 17. Unemployment Benefit was introduced in July 1991 and has been administered by the ES. At present, a Comrnission, meeting in the local Employment Office, grants the status of 'unemployed' and determines the rate and duration of payment. Arrangements are then made to pay the clients fortnightly by cheque. The payment for retrenched workers is calculated as a percentage of their average wage over the previous 12 weeks. Other workers, voluntarily unemployed or with no work history in the previous 12 months, including former students, are paid at the minimum wage level. There is a period of three months' disqualification for those who left their job voluntarily or violated the labor laws. Barriers 18. There are a number of barriers which unemployed people face when seeking to apply for assistance: - Potential clients are unaware of the ES and its activities, particularly the payment of Unemployment Benefit; - The admission procedures are cumbersome and the Commission acts as a deterrent to claiming; - The level of payment for Unemployment Benefit, particularly for those who would be paid at the minimum wage, is near worthless when considering the cost of living; 3 There appears to be an element of embarrassment associated with registering as unemployed and more particularly with receiving Unemployment Benefit; * There appears to be concerns about having the "work book" stamped as having been given the status of unemployed; and * The employment offices do not provide an inviting atmosphere. This barrier could be a combination of the physical surroundings, the office location and the attitude of staff. Unemployment Benefit Policy 19. No application is completed but staff submit cases to the Commission for consideration only if there is no possibility of the ES finding a job for the client. If a client attends the office looking for work and there are no job available through the ES and it is considered unlikely that jobs would become available in the short term, there is no reason why the status of unemployed cannot be declared on the first day the client visits the office providing he has ceasing working. The commencement of benefit would still be a separate decision but the client should still be told about possible entitlement and the process to realize the entitlement. This proposal contains all relevant information to determine entitlement, commencement date and the duration of benefit. The Commission is made up of a group of specialists from within each office. In some offices, this Commission has up to seven members, although generally, the number is much less. In smaller offices, a Commission of 4 or 5 would represent the whole staff. The Commission is used to ensure the consistency of decisions but, as the number of cases increase, the time required to deal with cases would become exorbitant.
 ANNEX 2 Page 12 Training and Development of Staff 25. The three tiers of management in the DOE have distinct but complementary responsibilities for staff training and development. The Republic Office is responsible for national training policies and strategies; development of a national training plan; organization of specialist training for management; and monitoring of training activity and standards. The Oblast office is responsible for developing strategic training responses to identified needs in Raion offices and providing assistance to Raion managers in determining of training needs and evaluation of training activity. The Raion office is responsible for these activities within its office and for providing induction training for new staff. 26. The need for increased focus on training and development has been a constant theme during discussions with executive and operational management. The same message also came from the directions paper produced from the Pavlodar regional managers conference in May 1994, from responses tot he survey questionnaire developed by the consultants for completion by key managers at all levels within the Department and from the seminars with operational staff conducted by consultants. 27. There is recognition that greater attention to development and training will lead to increased efficiencies, more flexibility to respond to changing workloads, increased job satisfaction and an improved image with the general community. Staff Training and Development 28. A skilled, flexible workforce is an essential requirement for any organization, particularly where delivery of decentralized services is involved. The move towards a market economy, increasing volumes of job seekers and changing expectations from enterprises and jobseekers, will all present new demands on the Department of Employment, especially at the operational level. Competency Based Approach 29. A first step in the implementation process is the introduction of a basic Competency Based Approach (CBA) to staff training and development. The approach can be relatively simple, quick to introduce, cost efficient, and effective. Furthermore, it provides the basic for enhancement as the ES develops over the coming years. The competencies should become the basis for identifying training needs by providing the benchmarks against which individual staff are assessed - the process involves appraisal of an individual's competencies against their job(s) requirements.  KAZAKHSTAN SOCIAL PROTECTION PROJECT ANNEX 2B. GENDER TARGETED TRAINING A. Background 1. The Kazakhstan Government has a commitment to providing vocational training, retraining and upgrading to the unemployed. In 1991 the Government established a Republic Center for Vocational and Professional Training under the Ministry of Labor, with a central office in Almaty and regional offices in each of the 19 Oblasts. The training centers (TCs) provide information, screening facilities and training assistance to registered unemployed persons considered eligible for the scheme. Training courses are mainly sub-contracted from public education institutes in the immediate locality, including vocational schools, technical colleges and higher education institutes. A limited number of training centers offer courses directly, ranging from arts and crafts to auto-mechanics. The capacity to offer courses directly depends on the material location and conditions of each of the centers, which varies widely. Trainees are provided with allowances to participate in training courses which are based on past salary levels and work experience. Trainees without work experience are paid at the level of the minimum wage or unemployment benefit, which ever is greater, plus a IOOT transport allowance. 2. The present system of vocational training for the unemployed has some strengths and a number of weaknesses. On the positive side, training for the unemployed is being handled outside the Employment Offices. EOs direct potential trainees to the Centers, but are not involved in either assessing or placing trainees in courses. On the negative side, Directors of the TCs report both to the Chief of the Oblast EO and the Director of the Republic Training Center, which create tension over the way in which the Centers should run. Again on the positive side, the majority of courses offered by the centers are sub-contracted. On the negative side the Centers sub-contract only to the state education system which is probably the slowest of all state institutions to respond to changes in the economic environment. Courses are often out of date, narrowly defined and out of touch with the demand side of the labor market. Courses offered to women, for example, tend to reflect stereotypes of the work women are being expected to do rather than any understanding of what the market is actually demanding. Some state training institutions are beginning to offer business management, and computer training courses, although trainers are ill-equipped to provide state of the art curricula in these areas. 3. At least two fairly sizable private sector training institutions are operating in Kazakhstan, both based in Almaty. These are the Kazakhstan Institute of Management Economics (KIME), established in 1992, and the Kazakh-American International Business Institute (KAIBI), established in 1991. KIME offers two year degree courses in business administration and economics. KAIBI offers short term courses in market economics, business and management. As of November 1994, a further 19 organizations claimed to provide management training in Kazakhstan, although a USAID report on their activities indicated that most were offering only limited seminar-courses on management issues. There is nevertheless a general lack of credible training institutions in Kazakhstan. The absence of training explicitly for self-employment and small-enterprise is also a problem in Kazakhstan, especially where a dynamic and growing small business sector will be crucial not only because of the need to generate productive employment opportunities, but because of the critical role of these firms in building a new, decentralized market economy.

 KAZAKHSTAN SOCIAL PROTECTION PROJECT ANNEX 3. DETAILED FEATURES OF SOCIAL SERVICES COMPONENT A. Background 1. Traditionally enterprises - especially large ones - have often been responsible for provision of social services not only to their employees but also to the general population in their conmmunities. These services included housing and related utilities, healthcare, kindergartens, community facilities (cultural, recreational and sport), summer camps and dormitories. Local governments provided similar municipal services in parallel. The share of municipal and enterprise services varied, depending on the local productive profile, and the comparative financial and administrative capacity of local authorities and enterprises. For example, in Almaty municipal services dominated, while those provided by enterprises were limited and targeted primarily to enterprise employees. In smaller communities, dominated by one or several large enterprises, firms have delivered the bulk of services. 2. With hardening budget constraints and privatization of state-owned enterprises, firms have begun divesting non-productive assets and in many cases have transferred facilities to local governments. When a municipality is unable to accommodate additional facilities, case-by-case solutions are being sought, including: (a) enterprises transfer ownership of facilities to local administrations, but continue financial support for an interim period; (b) enterprises close social services and commercialize the premises; and (c) enterprises continue to provide some basic services, including operating costs in the costs of general production. 3. In order to preserve essential social services, the Govermnent is seeking strategic solutions to this problem, including preparing - with project support - a national strategy for dealing with divestiture of enterprise social assets, and ensuring continued access to essential social services. As far as housing is concerned, the Government believes that the main avenue of discharging enterprises from expenditures is to deepen privatization. However, this complex issue is being addressed separately. It was agreed at identification that the Project would focus only on selected health facilities (polyclinics and hospitals), and kindergartens. As the first step in developing a meaningful divestiture strategy, local governments need to assess the essential facilities which they are able to sustain. All other services would need to be privatized, closed or retained by enterprises without state support. In many cases facilities with low rates of occupancy could be amalgamated. 4. As a long-term solution for sustained development of social services, broader sectoral approaches are needed. Reforms to the health care system have been proposed by MOH in provision, financing and management. New operating and financing principles in the health sector would contribute to sustainable development of public health services. The Project focuses primarily on restructuring of municipal financial mechanisms rather than on broader sectoral changes, though it seeks to facilitate implementation of such reforms in the pilot oblasts. 5. A clear definition of the social role of kindergartens needs to be developed. In some cases they are primarily day care institutions facilitating female employment. In others, they are early child development centers, since they provide pre-school education, primary medical care, nutrition, inununization etc. Yet the coverage rate nationally is only around 40%, in some cases due to the limited capacity of the system. Though more work is being completed under the project on the incidence and impact of state-funded kindergartens, a critical minimum of kindergartens should be preserved in each project city in the short term. In parallel with Project inplementation, the Government should revise
 Page 41 ANNEX 3 the principles covering access to kindergartens within the framework of a national strategy for social services. 6. Both national and local governments should also consider the commercial aspects of the divestiture process. While most enterprises are keen to divest themselves of social services, they are often not keen to divest themselves of the assets which have commercial value as real estate. While some flexibility should be given to companies to choose whether to retain social services or not, in cases where social facilities are closed and premises are commercialized, local governments may need to support divestiture of assets for the benefit of the community, or develop arrangements for allocation of leasing revenues. 7. The Project assumes that in the context of local budget constraints, the only ways to sustain essential social services in a community are to: (a) undertake comprehensive rationalization of social expenditures; (b) raise cost effectiveness of services; and (c) bring total social spending into line with local budgetary constraints. 8. There are various options in developing city-specific rationalization strategies, including: (a) Amalgamation of services. Released assets could be used for commercial purposes, thus contributing to modest revenue increases for local budgets; (b) Improved targeting of social services for vulnerable groups; (c) Introduction/increases of userfees, through charges for selected medical services, and increased fees in budget kindergartens (with appropriate exemption schedules); (d) Privatization of non-essential services. These services could be targeted to the higher end of the consumer market, and provide optional services in education and health care of higher quality; and (e) Closure of some facilities in cases where: (i) there is over-supply; and/or (ii) the community can not properly finance them. B. Project Approach to Individual Types of Social Assets Kindergartens 9. Kindergartens play a broader role in education and child-care in Kazakhstan and other FSU countries than they do in Western countries. Children attend from around 2 years of age until primary school (at the age of 6-7). Attendance, however, has never been universal and has recently fallen to around 40% of the respective age group. The major coverage is in urban areas. 10. In 1992-93 the share of enterprise-owned kindergartens declined from 72% to 60%. The decline appears to have accelerated in many regions since that time. Trying to sustain the kindergarten system in both the budget and enterprise sectors, the Government has allowed increases in user fees up to 30% of food costs. However, a generous fee exemption and reduction schedule has resulted in lower than expected fee revenues. The project seeks to support continued kindergarten provision, by promoting more cost effective operation (e.g. improved food procurement practices; revision of specialist teacher ratios), and support for a more transparent and better enforced fee schedule.
 ANNEX 3 Page 42 Medical Facilities 11. Three types of medical facilities are operated by enterprises: polyclinics, hospitals and sanatoria. Polyclinics provide basic health care. Though they offer basic health care services, they are staffed by health specialists, since there has traditionally been no general practitioner training in Kazakhstan. In developing methods for more effective polyclinic service delivery, a number of issues arise which relate also to the operation of hospitals (e.g. referral practices). 12. Local governments already run most hospitals, though some enterprises "sponsor" facilities, contributing to selected expenditures. In the two oblast capitals (Shymkent and Pavlodar cities), there are also a number of oblast hospitals, which perform certain central functions for the whole region. These operate to a significant degree in an integrated manner with municipal hospitals (e.g. common emergency rosters, centralization of common functions). The size and cost of the health system in project cities will not increase to any significant degree as a result of divestiture. The overwhelming majority of hospitals and polyclinics are already on the budget, so that the bed/facility increment is marginal. The project would support an integrated approach to provision of different levels of healthcare in the participating cities. C. Features of Project Design and Implementation 13. The Social Service Component is of a pilot nature. It would provide support to five cities in two oblasts: Shymkent, Kentau, Lenger (South Kazakhstan oblast), Pavlodar and Aksu (Pavlodar oblast). The five cities have different economic and demographic conditions, so that models developed will provide lessons for replication in various parts of the country. 14. While overall implementation responsibility for the project remains with the central Government - which has established a PCU in the MOF to coordinate project activities - implementation of the Social Services Component will be done predominantly by the administrations of the two oblasts and five cities. Local and oblast administrations have been involved in project preparation since its early stages. They have developed rationalization proposals, and draft first year work programs have already been prepared as a condition of negotiations. The project will finance necessary technical assistance. In particular, technical assistance and training will be provided in: (a) financial management; (b) sector-specific mnanagement practices in health care and early education (including specialized procurement); (c) strategic and operational planning; (d) monitoring and evaluation; and (e) staff and management training. 15. The Project will be carefully monitored, partly to ensure effective implementation, partly to identify improvements in social service policy and provision that would inform a national strategy.
 Pafe 43 ANNEX 3 16. Under the Loan, the following types of expenditures would be financed: (a) modest rehabilitation and upgrading of selected health and kindergarten facilities financed by the budget, regardless of their origin (ex-enterprise or existing municipal); (b) purchase of critical supplies and equipment for selected budget medical and kindergarten facilities (medical equipment, drugs, vaccines, textbooks, kitchen equipment), regardless of their origin; and (c) financing of recurrent costs of divested facilities on a declining basis with a condition of local co-financing. D. Sustainability of Services 17. In the long run sustainability of local social services can only be ensured with general increases in productivity and tax revenues which are a direct result of economic growth and strengthening of tax administration. This would be a key feature for replicating project models nationwide. However, it is also crucial to ensure short term support for social services under the present pilot project. Estimates show that while in most localities this is feasible, in Kentau, the financing gap emerging with the increase of publicly supported social facilities will be difficult to bridge by rationalization, cost recovery and privatization. Such localities with low tax base would require some support from the oblast and/or central budget, at least in the medium-term. 18. Sustainability requires that cost increases for kindergartens as a result of divestiture are offset by the end of the project by: (i) rationalization/cost savings in the health sector on an almost constant number of budget hospitals/polyclinics; (ii) fee revenue, from introduction of health care user charges and increases in kindergarten fees; and (iii) reduction of inefficiencies within the municipal kindergarten system, resulting in savings without affecting quality of service (e.g. more competitive procurement practices). Provided these reforms can be introduced in the five cities, the Government wil not be required to spend any more in real terms after the project than it does currently on the selected services, despite the fact that the transfer of social assets is initially adding an average across the five cities of around 20% to local social expenditures. 19. Given a health system where initial costs are roughly the same, the project aims to facilitate/leverage significant cost reductions and new sources of revenue over project life, to ensure a more affordable system (with the caveat that broad sectoral reforms are not the objective of the project). Cost reductions could be of several types, including: (a) closure and merger of small specialist facilities into departments of general hospitals. This will save substantial amounts in utilities costs (which run up to one third of total facility costs), even if all staff etc. are transferred to the other facility. Savings will be higher if some staff can be encouraged to set up private practices; (b) centralization of services for hospitals (e.g. laboratory; equipment repair/maintenance) which are currently duplicated in inefficient ways; (c) revision of treatment protocols nearer to international standards, to reduce high average length of stay for non-acute patients; and (d) introduction of revised payment mechanisms, such as capitation or fee-for-service. The two main options for new sources of financing are: (i) introduction of user fees for selected health services; and/or (ii) introduction of mandatory health insurance (with locally generated revenues preferably kept at the local level). The Government in its Memorandum of Understanding (Annex 1), has indicated that it is considering introduction of both options as a priority.

 KAZAKHSTAN SOCIAL PROTECTION PROJECT ANNEX 3B. RATIONALIZATION PLANS A. Background 1. The central element in the Social Services Component is development and implementation of framework rationalization plans and detailed annual work programs (WPs) for each of the participating cities. While the plans and work programs would give clear outlines for efficient social service expenditures, there would remain some flexibility in implementation, as rapidly changing economic circumstances dictated. 2. Detailed 1995 WPs have been prepared for each participating city in both South Kazakhstan and Pavlodar oblasts. The WPs detail activities to take place in the cities concerned during the first year of the project as restructuring of the enterprise sector continues and social assets are transferred from enterprises. The priority facilities included in the project are kindergartens, polyclinics and hospitals. The actual pace and magnitude of the divestiture have been assessed and tailored to the particular circumstances of each locality. WPs would be prepared and reviewed annually, and an assessment made of implementation of the previous years' program. 3. The project has already provided assistance to local administrations in development of detailed programs for transfer and restructuring of social assets, management improvements and implementation of framework rationalization plans. Implementation of AWPs is expected to lead to savings and increased efficiency in the management of kindergartens, hospitals, and polyclinics through the removal of constraints such as underutilized capacity, duplication of services, weak financial and budgetary management, inefficient equipment purchase and maintenance, and uncompetitive food procurement practices. 4. The detailed AWPs are based on the framework provided by the rationalization plans. They are to be prepared annually by ad-hoc working groups within each local administration, which have been assisted by external consultants in preparation of first year work programs. The first step for each locality was to update the inventory of enterprise and municipal social assets and make an assessment of their level of utilization, need for physical rehabilitation, and equipment and supply requirements. Based on the information obtained, a first year asset consolidation plan has been prepared, including detailed reconmmendations for closing or merging of facilities. A rehabilitation, equipment and supply purchasing plan has also been defined. For enterprise assets, discussions have been and will continue to be held with enterprise managers to reach agreement on an appropriate timetable for transfer of assets in a manner consistent with the capacity of local administrations to manage them and finance resulting incremental costs. 5. Management Efficiency Improvements. The investments to be financed under the project will not produce the desired results if overall management of social assets is not improved. The project includes technical assistance to local and national administrators in the areas of financial and budgetary management and expenditure control and reporting. Assistance would be directed particularly towards developing sector-specific management skills in the health and education sectors, so that, in addition to the benefits in facilities supported by the project, there would be efficiency gains in the management of primary and secondary education. A number of fellowships and study tours would also be provided, in order to give local and national officials exposure to effective management practices in other countries. By including national officials in training, the benefits of lessons learnt during project implementation can be incorporated into rationalization programs in other parts of the country.

In each of the five localities divestiture of social assets would cause - even with project support - emergence of a new financing gap in local budgets. Amounts were analyzed and have been compared with several variables, such as: projected total local fiscal revenues; projected additional revenues resulting from divestitures only; total recurrent costs of the to-be sustained facilities; project financing of recurrent costs. Analysis shows that in the first two years none of the localities experience severe difficulties in covering the gap. During Year 3 through Year 5 four of the five cities (excluding Kentau) would be in a position to cover the gap without major problems. The deficit expressed as a percentage of the total fiscal revenues varies from city to city. On average, it would increase from 1 % in the third year to just over 2% in the fifth year. Options to close the deficit gap include an increase in the level of cost recovery, an increase in the tax sharing rate of the oblasts, further reduction in unit operating costs and more efficiency improvements. 13. After the end of the proposed project, when the localities would need to finance not only 100% of recurrent costs but also critical supplies, two cities - Kentau and Pavlodar - would need to raise their revenues significantly. In the case of Pavlodar, this is clearly feasible, due to the large size of the city, its broad local fiscal base, and ample opportunities for private sector development. In the case of Kentau, the situation is different and requires further analysis. 14. Thus, with extensive and systematic rationalization of social services, managerial and financial sustainability of services could be attained in all localities (with the possible exception of Kentau). In each of the cities, significant net reductions of total social expenditures would take place in the course of project implementation, thus diminishing pressure on local and central budgets. The main conclusion from the analysis is that, while rationalization proposed under the project would be a

 KAZAKHSTAN SOCIAL PROTECTION PROJECT ANNEX 3C. MONITORING AND EVALUATION OF SOCIAL SERVICES 1. Project implementation would take place in an experimental setting with many unknown factors including the administrative capacity of the cities. It is therefore advisable to provide a simple but effective system for monitoring and evaluation so that progress and the effective utilization of project resources can be properly followed and when problems are identified, measures can be put in place to rectify the situation. 2. The design of the monitoring and evaluation system to be used by the project would be done by the technical assistance team in close association with the oblast and city administration officials. A. Monitoring 3. Monitoring would be carried out in four main areas: (i) the procurement and physical delivery of goods; (ii) the physical implementation of project activities; (iii) the financial management and control of project funds; and (iv) the institutional development under the project. A continuous assessment of these activities would be carried out under the context of the implementation schedule and, more specifically, the annual work programs. 4. The monitoring function would use the project's Management Information System (MIS) to be designed by the technical assistance team with the active participation of the implementation agencies (oblasts and cities) and more specifically the Component Coordinators. The terms of referene of the financial management and accounting experts include helping design the MIS by first malin a thorough diagnostic of the existing budgetary and management systems of the cities and then makin concrete recommendations on ways to adapt and supplement them. 5. . On the basis of the objectives and the implementation parameters included in the Ammal Work Programs (AWP) and Budgets, the project would be monitored through well defined Performance Monitoring Indicators (Annex 7) indicators that will be included in the quarterly and annual report to be submitted to the oblast administrations, the PCU, the central Government and the Bank. These indicators are consistent with the references defined in the Project Implementation Schedule (Annex 9). The following key indicators would be monitored: (a) Asset transfer Number of assets or facilities transferred by nature and location (b) Restructuring By nature of asset: previous unit operating cost new unit operating cost previous number of assets

 ANNEX 3C Pane 84 (i) Social indicators - number of users before project per facility - number of users per unit during project - total number of users served before project - total number of users currently served (j) Financial indicators - unit costs: planned vs. actual for - rehabilitation - equipment - supplies - child - hospital - policlinic - total rehabilitation costs: planned vs. actual - total equipment costs: planned vs actual - total supplies costs: planned vs actual - total incremental recurrent costs: planned vs actual - disbursements: planned vs. actual B. Evaluation 6. The relevance, performance, effectiveness, efficiency and impact of the project activities within its stated objectives would be periodically evaluated using the monitoring data. The main purpose of these evaluations would be to draw lessons from the experience gained and to adjust project design and implementation accordingly. 7. In addition to the normal on-going evaluation that is normally done in development projects, the periodicity of other evaluation would be tailored to the special circumstances of both the project and Kazakhstan. The first evaluation would take place six months after the start of effective project implementation; the second one after one year; the third would be the mid-term evaluation and the final would be ex-post. C. Structure 8. The data required for project monitoring would be gathered and processed by the municipal financial and budgetary service staff with the assistance of the financial management and accounting experts financed by the project in close association with the city CCs. There would be no need therefore to create a special monitoring unit for the project. The evaluation function would be carried out by the oblast CCs and the PCU.

The current budgetary and financial management system still retains many features of the FSU system. Typically, the Ministry of Finance (MOF) requests from the oblasts proposals for the coming year budgets in terms of expenditures and possible revenue generation. Based on these proposals, the MOF allocates a budget to the oblast with broad guidelines on the allocation between different expenditure categories. The oblast council then meets to determine the final make-up of the budget among different categories within the ceiling assigned to them by the MOF. The final budget submitted to and approved by Parliament has a budget entry only for the oblasts, not the cities. 2. The oblast, like the MOF, allocates a budget amount to the cities or raions based on proposals received from them. The city and raion councils, in turn, decide on how to allocate the funds assigned to them between the different activities of their administration. 3. A major aspect of the procedures briefly defined above is that both the cities and the oblasts are not consulted on when the final decision is taken to allocate the budget amount to them. It is therefore basically a top down approach. Another important feature is that most of the taxes used to fund the budget are controlled by the central government which also decides each year the revenue or tax sharing rate between the central government and the oblasts. The oblasts in turn determine the level of tax sharing for the cities and raions. A third feature is the apparent lack of adequate coordination between the process of establishing tax sharing rates on the one hand and the establishment and approval of expenditures on the other at the oblast and city level. A final characteristic of the current system is that the oblast is the focal point of budgetary and financial management at the regional level. The cities have no direct relationship with the MOF and depend entirely on the oblast administration. 4. Kazakhstan's budgetary and financial reporting mechanisms are not yet well known but appear to be deficient in many ways. This is due in part to the delays in approving the budget and to high inflation levels which require repeated budget revisions during the year. The 1994 budget for instance was revised at least nine times and was only approved by Parliament in December 1994. Budget reports for 1993 were not available at the end of November; it is therefore difficult to assess the budget figures provided, a key element in determining how reliable and effective the funds flow mechanisms are. doc.abstracts: The Social Protection Project seeks to: 1) develop the capacity of the Employment Service in the Department of Employment (DOE) of the Ministry of Labor (MOL) to manage the expected increase in the number of registered unemployed and attendant benefit claims following the restructuring and privatization of enterprises; and 2) ensure continued delivery of essential social services, by promoting orderly divestiture of social assets from enterprises, and efficient management by municipalities of a unified system of social services. To meet these objectives, the project has two main components: 1) an Employment Service (ES) Component to be implemented at both national and regional levels; and a Social Services Component, to be implemented in selected cities of South Kazakstan and Pavlodar oblasts. The Employment Service (ES) Component will strengthen the institutional capacity of the ES to register the unemployed and calculate and pay unemployment benefits; provide a more effective service to unemployed jobseekers; and analyze labor markets and formulate labor market policies. The Social Services Component will facilitate the transfer of essential social services from restructuring enterprises to local governments, and rationalize management of all basic services in five selected cities : Shymkent City, Kentau, Lenger, Pavlodar City, and Aksu.
